speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Woods and cave, near the seashore.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter TIMON, from the cave

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Infect the air! Twinn'd brothers of one womb,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Whose procreation, residence, and birth,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The greater scorns the lesser: not nature,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortune,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But by contempt of nature.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Raise me this beggar, and deny 't that lord;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The senator shall bear contempt hereditary,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The beggar native honour.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: It is the pasture lards the rother's sides,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The want that makes him lean. Who dares, who dares,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: In purity of manhood stand upright,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And say 'This man's a flatterer?' if one be,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: So are they all; for every grise of fortune

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Is smooth'd by that below: the learned pate

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ducks to the golden fool: all is oblique;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: There's nothing level in our cursed natures,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But direct villany. Therefore, be abhorr'd

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: All feasts, societies, and throngs of men!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Digging

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With thy most operant poison! What is here?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Gold? yellow, glittering, precious gold? No, gods,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I am no idle votarist: roots, you clear heavens!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Thus much of this will make black white, foul fair,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Wrong right, base noble, old young, coward valiant.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ha, you gods! why this? what this, you gods? Why, this

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Will lug your priests and servants from your sides,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pluck stout men's pillows from below their heads:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: This yellow slave

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Will knit and break religions, bless the accursed,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Make the hoar leprosy adored, place thieves

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And give them title, knee and approbation

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With senators on the bench: this is it

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That makes the wappen'd widow wed again;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: She, whom the spital-house and ulcerous sores

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To the April day again. Come, damned earth,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Thou common whore of mankind, that put'st odds

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Among the route of nations, I will make thee

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Do thy right nature.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: March afar off

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ha! a drum ? Thou'rt quick,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But yet I'll bury thee: thou'lt go, strong thief,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Nay, stay thou out for earnest.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Keeping some gold

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in warlike manner; PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: What art thou there? speak.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For showing me again the eyes of man!

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: That art thyself a man?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That I might love thee something.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I know thee well;

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: But in thy fortunes am unlearn'd and strange.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I know thee too; and more than that I know thee,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I not desire to know. Follow thy drum;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With man's blood paint the ground, gules, gules:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Religious canons, civil laws are cruel;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Then what should war be? This fell whore of thine

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hath in her more destruction than thy sword,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For all her cherubim look.

speaker: PHRYNIA
text_entry: Thy lips rot off!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I will not kiss thee; then the rot returns

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To thine own lips again.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: How came the noble Timon to this change?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As the moon does, by wanting light to give:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But then renew I could not, like the moon;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: There were no suns to borrow of.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Noble Timon,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: What friendship may I do thee?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: None, but to

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Maintain my opinion.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: What is it, Timon?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Promise me friendship, but perform none: if thou

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: wilt not promise, the gods plague thee, for thou art

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: a man! if thou dost perform, confound thee, for

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: thou art a man!

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I have heard in some sort of thy miseries.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou saw'st them, when I had prosperity.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I see them now; then was a blessed time.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As thine is now, held with a brace of harlots.

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Is this the Athenian minion, whom the world

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Voiced so regardfully?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Art thou Timandra?

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be a whore still: they love thee not that use thee;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Give them diseases, leaving with thee their lust.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Make use of thy salt hours: season the slaves

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For tubs and baths; bring down rose-cheeked youth

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To the tub-fast and the diet.

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Hang thee, monster!

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Pardon him, sweet Timandra; for his wits

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Are drown'd and lost in his calamities.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I have but little gold of late, brave Timon,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: The want whereof doth daily make revolt

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: In my penurious band: I have heard, and grieved,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: How cursed Athens, mindless of thy worth,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Forgetting thy great deeds, when neighbour states,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: But for thy sword and fortune, trod upon them,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I prithee, beat thy drum, and get thee gone.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I am thy friend, and pity thee, dear Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I had rather be alone.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Why, fare thee well:

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Here is some gold for thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Keep it, I cannot eat it.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: When I have laid proud Athens on a heap,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Warr'st thou 'gainst Athens?

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Ay, Timon, and have cause.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The gods confound them all in thy conquest;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And thee after, when thou hast conquer'd!

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Why me, Timon?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That, by killing of villains,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou wast born to conquer my country.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Put up thy gold: go on,--here's gold,--go on;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be as a planetary plague, when Jove

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Will o'er some high-viced city hang his poison

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In the sick air: let not thy sword skip one:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Pity not honour'd age for his white beard;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: He is an usurer: strike me the counterfeit matron;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: It is her habit only that is honest,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Herself's a bawd: let not the virgin's cheek

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Make soft thy trenchant sword; for those milk-paps,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That through the window-bars bore at men's eyes,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Are not within the leaf of pity writ,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But set them down horrible traitors: spare not the babe,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whose dimpled smiles from fools exhaust their mercy;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Think it a bastard, whom the oracle

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hath doubtfully pronounced thy throat shall cut,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And mince it sans remorse: swear against objects;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Put armour on thine ears and on thine eyes;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whose proof, nor yells of mothers, maids, nor babes,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nor sight of priests in holy vestments bleeding,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Shall pierce a jot. There's gold to pay soldiers:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Make large confusion; and, thy fury spent,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Confounded be thyself! Speak not, be gone.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Hast thou gold yet? I'll take the gold thou

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: givest me,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Not all thy counsel.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Dost thou, or dost thou not, heaven's curse

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: upon thee!

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Give us some gold, good Timon: hast thou more?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enough to make a whore forswear her trade,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And to make whores, a bawd. Hold up, you sluts,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Your aprons mountant: you are not oathable,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Although, I know, you 'll swear, terribly swear

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Into strong shudders and to heavenly agues

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The immortal gods that hear you,--spare your oaths,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll trust to your conditions: be whores still;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And he whose pious breath seeks to convert you,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be strong in whore, allure him, burn him up;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let your close fire predominate his smoke,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And be no turncoats: yet may your pains, six months,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be quite contrary: and thatch your poor thin roofs

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With burthens of the dead;--some that were hang'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: No matter:--wear them, betray with them: whore still;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Paint till a horse may mire upon your face,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A pox of wrinkles!

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Well, more gold: what then?

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: Believe't, that we'll do any thing for gold.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Consumptions sow

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In hollow bones of man; strike their sharp shins,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And mar men's spurring. Crack the lawyer's voice,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That he may never more false title plead,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nor sound his quillets shrilly: hoar the flamen,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That scolds against the quality of flesh,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And not believes himself: down with the nose,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Down with it flat; take the bridge quite away

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of him that, his particular to foresee,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Smells from the general weal: make curl'd-pate

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: ruffians bald;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And let the unscarr'd braggarts of the war

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Derive some pain from you: plague all;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That your activity may defeat and quell

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The source of all erection. There's more gold:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Do you damn others, and let this damn you,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And ditches grave you all!

speaker: TIMANDRA
text_entry: More counsel with more money, bounteous Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: More whore, more mischief first; I have given you earnest.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Strike up the drum towards Athens! Farewell, Timon:

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: If I thrive well, I'll visit thee again.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If I hope well, I'll never see thee more.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I never did thee harm.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Yes, thou spokest well of me.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Call'st thou that harm?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Men daily find it. Get thee away, and take

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thy beagles with thee.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: We but offend him. Strike!

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Drum beats. Exeunt ALCIBIADES, PHRYNIA, and TIMANDRA

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That nature, being sick of man's unkindness,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Should yet be hungry! Common mother, thou,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Digging

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whose womb unmeasurable, and infinite breast,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Teems, and feeds all; whose self-same mettle,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whereof thy proud child, arrogant man, is puff'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Engenders the black toad and adder blue,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The gilded newt and eyeless venom'd worm,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With all the abhorred births below crisp heaven

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whereon Hyperion's quickening fire doth shine;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Yield him, who all thy human sons doth hate,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: From forth thy plenteous bosom, one poor root!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let it no more bring out ingrateful man!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go great with tigers, dragons, wolves, and bears;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Teem with new monsters, whom thy upward face

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hath to the marbled mansion all above

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Never presented!--O, a root,--dear thanks!--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Dry up thy marrows, vines, and plough-torn leas;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whereof ungrateful man, with liquorish draughts

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And morsels unctuous, greases his pure mind,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That from it all consideration slips!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter APEMANTUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: More man? plague, plague!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I was directed hither: men report

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou dost affect my manners, and dost use them.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis, then, because thou dost not keep a dog,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whom I would imitate: consumption catch thee!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: This is in thee a nature but infected;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: A poor unmanly melancholy sprung

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: From change of fortune. Why this spade? this place?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: This slave-like habit? and these looks of care?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thy flatterers yet wear silk, drink wine, lie soft;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Hug their diseased perfumes, and have forgot

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That ever Timon was. Shame not these woods,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: By putting on the cunning of a carper.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Be thou a flatterer now, and seek to thrive

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: By that which has undone thee: hinge thy knee,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And let his very breath, whom thou'lt observe,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Blow off thy cap; praise his most vicious strain,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And call it excellent: thou wast told thus;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou gavest thine ears like tapsters that bid welcome

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To knaves and all approachers: 'tis most just

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That thou turn rascal; hadst thou wealth again,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Rascals should have 't. Do not assume my likeness.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Were I like thee, I'ld throw away myself.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou hast cast away thyself, being like thyself;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: A madman so long, now a fool. What, think'st

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That the bleak air, thy boisterous chamberlain,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Will put thy shirt on warm? will these moss'd trees,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That have outlived the eagle, page thy heels,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And skip where thou point'st out? will the

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: cold brook,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Candied with ice, caudle thy morning taste,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To cure thy o'er-night's surfeit? Call the creatures

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Whose naked natures live in an the spite

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Of wreakful heaven, whose bare unhoused trunks,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To the conflicting elements exposed,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Answer mere nature; bid them flatter thee;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: O, thou shalt find--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A fool of thee: depart.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I love thee better now than e'er I did.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I hate thee worse.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Why?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou flatter'st misery.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I flatter not; but say thou art a caitiff.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why dost thou seek me out?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To vex thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Always a villain's office or a fool's.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Dost please thyself in't?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What! a knave too?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: If thou didst put this sour-cold habit on

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To castigate thy pride, 'twere well: but thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Dost it enforcedly; thou'ldst courtier be again,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Wert thou not beggar. Willing misery

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Outlives encertain pomp, is crown'd before:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The one is filling still, never complete;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The other, at high wish: best state, contentless,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Hath a distracted and most wretched being,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Worse than the worst, content.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou shouldst desire to die, being miserable.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Not by his breath that is more miserable.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art a slave, whom Fortune's tender arm

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With favour never clasp'd; but bred a dog.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hadst thou, like us from our first swath, proceeded

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The sweet degrees that this brief world affords

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To such as may the passive drugs of it

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Freely command, thou wouldst have plunged thyself

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In general riot; melted down thy youth

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In different beds of lust; and never learn'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The icy precepts of respect, but follow'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The sugar'd game before thee. But myself,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Who had the world as my confectionary,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The mouths, the tongues, the eyes and hearts of men

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: At duty, more than I could frame employment,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That numberless upon me stuck as leaves

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Do on the oak, hive with one winter's brush

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Fell from their boughs and left me open, bare

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For every storm that blows: I, to bear this,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That never knew but better, is some burden:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thy nature did commence in sufferance, time

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hath made thee hard in't. Why shouldst thou hate men?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They never flatter'd thee: what hast thou given?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If thou wilt curse, thy father, that poor rag,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Must be thy subject, who in spite put stuff

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To some she beggar and compounded thee

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Poor rogue hereditary. Hence, be gone!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If thou hadst not been born the worst of men,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Art thou proud yet?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ay, that I am not thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I, that I was

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No prodigal.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I, that I am one now:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Were all the wealth I have shut up in thee,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'ld give thee leave to hang it. Get thee gone.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That the whole life of Athens were in this!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thus would I eat it.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Eating a root

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Here; I will mend thy feast.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Offering him a root

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: First mend my company, take away thyself.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So I shall mend mine own, by the lack of thine.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis not well mended so, it is but botch'd;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: if not, I would it were.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: What wouldst thou have to Athens?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thee thither in a whirlwind. If thou wilt,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Tell them there I have gold; look, so I have.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Here is no use for gold.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The best and truest;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For here it sleeps, and does no hired harm.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Where liest o' nights, Timon?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Under that's above me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Where feed'st thou o' days, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Where my stomach finds meat; or, rather, where I eat

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: it.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Would poison were obedient and knew my mind!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Where wouldst thou send it?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To sauce thy dishes.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The middle of humanity thou never knewest, but the

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: extremity of both ends: when thou wast in thy gilt

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: and thy perfume, they mocked thee for too much

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: curiosity; in thy rags thou knowest none, but art

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: despised for the contrary. There's a medlar for

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: thee, eat it.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: On what I hate I feed not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Dost hate a medlar?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ay, though it look like thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: An thou hadst hated meddlers sooner, thou shouldst

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: have loved thyself better now. What man didst thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: ever know unthrift that was beloved after his means?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Who, without those means thou talkest of, didst thou

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: ever know beloved?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Myself.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I understand thee; thou hadst some means to keep a

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: dog.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: What things in the world canst thou nearest compare

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: to thy flatterers?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Women nearest; but men, men are the things

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: themselves. What wouldst thou do with the world,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Apemantus, if it lay in thy power?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Give it the beasts, to be rid of the men.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wouldst thou have thyself fall in the confusion of

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: men, and remain a beast with the beasts?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay, Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A beastly ambition, which the gods grant thee t'

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: attain to! If thou wert the lion, the fox would

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: beguile thee; if thou wert the lamb, the fox would

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: eat three: if thou wert the fox, the lion would

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: suspect thee, when peradventure thou wert accused by

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: the ass: if thou wert the ass, thy dulness would

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: torment thee, and still thou livedst but as a

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: breakfast to the wolf: if thou wert the wolf, thy

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: greediness would afflict thee, and oft thou shouldst

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: hazard thy life for thy dinner: wert thou the

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: unicorn, pride and wrath would confound thee and

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: make thine own self the conquest of thy fury: wert

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: thou a bear, thou wouldst be killed by the horse:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: wert thou a horse, thou wouldst be seized by the

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: leopard: wert thou a leopard, thou wert german to

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: the lion and the spots of thy kindred were jurors on

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: thy life: all thy safety were remotion and thy

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: defence absence. What beast couldst thou be, that

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: were not subject to a beast? and what a beast art

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: thou already, that seest not thy loss in

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: transformation!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: If thou couldst please me with speaking to me, thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: mightst have hit upon it here: the commonwealth of

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Athens is become a forest of beasts.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How has the ass broke the wall, that thou art out of the city?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Yonder comes a poet and a painter: the plague of

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: company light upon thee! I will fear to catch it

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: and give way: when I know not what else to do, I'll

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: see thee again.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: When there is nothing living but thee, thou shalt be

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: welcome. I had rather be a beggar's dog than Apemantus.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: A plague on thee! thou art too bad to curse.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: All villains that do stand by thee are pure.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: There is no leprosy but what thou speak'st.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If I name thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll beat thee, but I should infect my hands.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I would my tongue could rot them off!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Away, thou issue of a mangy dog!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Choler does kill me that thou art alive;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I swound to see thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would thou wouldst burst!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Away,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou tedious rogue! I am sorry I shall lose

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A stone by thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Throws a stone at him

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Beast!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Slave!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Toad!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Rogue, rogue, rogue!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am sick of this false world, and will love nought

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But even the mere necessities upon 't.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Then, Timon, presently prepare thy grave;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lie where the light foam the sea may beat

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thy grave-stone daily: make thine epitaph,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That death in me at others' lives may laugh.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To the gold

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O thou sweet king-killer, and dear divorce

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Twixt natural son and sire! thou bright defiler

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of Hymen's purest bed! thou valiant Mars!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou ever young, fresh, loved and delicate wooer,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whose blush doth thaw the consecrated snow

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That lies on Dian's lap! thou visible god,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That solder'st close impossibilities,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And makest them kiss! that speak'st with

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: every tongue,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To every purpose! O thou touch of hearts!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Think, thy slave man rebels, and by thy virtue

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Set them into confounding odds, that beasts

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: May have the world in empire!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would 'twere so!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: But not till I am dead. I'll say thou'st gold:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou wilt be throng'd to shortly.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Throng'd to!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thy back, I prithee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Live, and love thy misery.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Long live so, and so die.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit APEMANTUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am quit.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Moe things like men! Eat, Timon, and abhor them.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter Banditti

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: Where should he have this gold? It is some poor

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: fragment, some slender sort of his remainder: the

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: mere want of gold, and the falling-from of his

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: friends, drove him into this melancholy.

speaker: Second Bandit
text_entry: It is noised he hath a mass of treasure.

speaker: Third Bandit
text_entry: Let us make the assay upon him: if he care not

speaker: Third Bandit
text_entry: for't, he will supply us easily; if he covetously

speaker: Third Bandit
text_entry: reserve it, how shall's get it?

speaker: Second Bandit
text_entry: True; for he bears it not about him, 'tis hid.

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: Is not this he?

speaker: Banditti
text_entry: Where?

speaker: Second Bandit
text_entry: 'Tis his description.

speaker: Third Bandit
text_entry: He; I know him.

speaker: Banditti
text_entry: Save thee, Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Now, thieves?

speaker: Banditti
text_entry: Soldiers, not thieves.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Both too; and women's sons.

speaker: Banditti
text_entry: We are not thieves, but men that much do want.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Your greatest want is, you want much of meat.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why should you want? Behold, the earth hath roots;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Within this mile break forth a hundred springs;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The oaks bear mast, the briers scarlet hips;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The bounteous housewife, nature, on each bush

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lays her full mess before you. Want! why want?

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: We cannot live on grass, on berries, water,

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: As beasts and birds and fishes.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nor on the beasts themselves, the birds, and fishes;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You must eat men. Yet thanks I must you con

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That you are thieves profess'd, that you work not

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In holier shapes: for there is boundless theft

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In limited professions. Rascal thieves,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Here's gold. Go, suck the subtle blood o' the grape,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Till the high fever seethe your blood to froth,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And so 'scape hanging: trust not the physician;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: His antidotes are poison, and he slays

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Moe than you rob: take wealth and lives together;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Do villany, do, since you protest to do't,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Like workmen. I'll example you with thievery.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The sun's a thief, and with his great attraction

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Robs the vast sea: the moon's an arrant thief,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And her pale fire she snatches from the sun:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The sea's a thief, whose liquid surge resolves

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The moon into salt tears: the earth's a thief,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That feeds and breeds by a composture stolen

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: From general excrement: each thing's a thief:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The laws, your curb and whip, in their rough power

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Have uncheque'd theft. Love not yourselves: away,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Rob one another. There's more gold. Cut throats:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: All that you meet are thieves: to Athens go,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Break open shops; nothing can you steal,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But thieves do lose it: steal no less for this

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I give you; and gold confound you howsoe'er! Amen.

speaker: Third Bandit
text_entry: Has almost charmed me from my profession, by

speaker: Third Bandit
text_entry: persuading me to it.

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: 'Tis in the malice of mankind that he thus advises

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: us; not to have us thrive in our mystery.

speaker: Second Bandit
text_entry: I'll believe him as an enemy, and give over my trade.

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: Let us first see peace in Athens: there is no time

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: so miserable but a man may be true.

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: Exeunt Banditti

speaker: First Bandit
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O you gods!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Is yond despised and ruinous man my lord?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Full of decay and failing? O monument

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And wonder of good deeds evilly bestow'd!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What an alteration of honour

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Has desperate want made!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What viler thing upon the earth than friends

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Who can bring noblest minds to basest ends!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How rarely does it meet with this time's guise,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When man was wish'd to love his enemies!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Grant I may ever love, and rather woo

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Those that would mischief me than those that do!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Has caught me in his eye: I will present

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My honest grief unto him; and, as my lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Still serve him with my life. My dearest master!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Away! what art thou?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Have you forgot me, sir?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why dost ask that? I have forgot all men;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Then, if thou grant'st thou'rt a man, I have forgot thee.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: An honest poor servant of yours.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Then I know thee not:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I never had honest man about me, I; all

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I kept were knaves, to serve in meat to villains.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The gods are witness,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ne'er did poor steward wear a truer grief

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For his undone lord than mine eyes for you.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What, dost thou weep? Come nearer. Then I

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: love thee,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Because thou art a woman, and disclaim'st

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Flinty mankind; whose eyes do never give

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But thorough lust and laughter. Pity's sleeping:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Strange times, that weep with laughing, not with weeping!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I beg of you to know me, good my lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To accept my grief and whilst this poor wealth lasts

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To entertain me as your steward still.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Had I a steward

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: So true, so just, and now so comfortable?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: It almost turns my dangerous nature mild.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let me behold thy face. Surely, this man

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Was born of woman.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Forgive my general and exceptless rashness,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You perpetual-sober gods! I do proclaim

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: One honest man--mistake me not--but one;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: No more, I pray,--and he's a steward.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How fain would I have hated all mankind!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And thou redeem'st thyself: but all, save thee,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I fell with curses.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Methinks thou art more honest now than wise;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For, by oppressing and betraying me,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou mightst have sooner got another service:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For many so arrive at second masters,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Upon their first lord's neck. But tell me true--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For I must ever doubt, though ne'er so sure--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is not thy kindness subtle, covetous,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If not a usuring kindness, and, as rich men deal gifts,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Expecting in return twenty for one?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: No, my most worthy master; in whose breast

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Doubt and suspect, alas, are placed too late:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: You should have fear'd false times when you did feast:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Suspect still comes where an estate is least.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That which I show, heaven knows, is merely love,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Duty and zeal to your unmatched mind,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Care of your food and living; and, believe it,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My most honour'd lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For any benefit that points to me,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Either in hope or present, I'ld exchange

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For this one wish, that you had power and wealth

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To requite me, by making rich yourself.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Look thee, 'tis so! Thou singly honest man,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Here, take: the gods out of my misery

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Have sent thee treasure. Go, live rich and happy;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But thus condition'd: thou shalt build from men;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hate all, curse all, show charity to none,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But let the famish'd flesh slide from the bone,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ere thou relieve the beggar; give to dogs

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What thou deny'st to men; let prisons swallow 'em,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Debts wither 'em to nothing; be men like

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: blasted woods,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And may diseases lick up their false bloods!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And so farewell and thrive.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O, let me stay,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And comfort you, my master.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If thou hatest curses,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Stay not; fly, whilst thou art blest and free:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ne'er see thou man, and let me ne'er see thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit FLAVIUS. TIMON retires to his cave
